componenttext: Great. And then just a follow-up on the non-energy [ph] businesses. You've done outstanding job the last 18 months driving consistent margin expansion in all of those businesses to offset the energy weakness. Has there -- I know you said you've been investing a lot, but is there a risk that if energy takes longer to come back that it just becomes much more difficult, I guess, particularly with raw's prices likely going up in the first half of next year to sustain the momentum on a constant currency basis? Obviously, FX look like it's going to be a lot less of a drag.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, Gary, I guess, the FX, it hits you in transaction and translation. And transaction is like inflation, and we mitigate that. But the translation, there's nothing to do. And FX has really been the problem that's been the most challenging for u
componenttext: Yes, I think, Gary, I guess, the FX, it hits you in transaction and translation. And transaction is like inflation, and we mitigate that. But the translation, there's nothing to do. And FX has really been the problem that's been the most challenging for us at the [ph] gate because it's not going to justify any pricing or driving pricing in the market. Raw materials, I think we've proven over the years that when the raws start moving, we typically can go command additional pricing as a consequence. We continue to drive mix through new technology upgrades in our customers, and of course, we've got the benefit to [ph] customers financially as well. And we've got what I would say very strong momentum in our supply chain around what we call structural savings. So I'm really not that nervous about what we believe is going to happen in the raw material markets, which we believe raws are going to move up next year, but we do believe we're [ph] going to move up in a fairly orderly fashion as we go, but we have that fully forecasted in our business. I don't think that's going to drive or negate our ability to continue to drive margin expansion in those businesses. And I would say we didn't drive margin just because oil was down. I mean, we were driving margin when oil was up in a number of those businesses. That's kind of our constant. We want profitable growth, continue to drive mix in a favorable way, watch our spending, continue to get productivity, and those are going to be the same focus areas next year as well.

componenttextpreview: Well, it's some of both, Nate. So certainly, a number of these initiatives have what I'll call long tail. They take a number of years to fully realize the benefits. And so a number of steps, but we're [ph] continuing to roll out new technology in the Inst
componenttext: Well, it's some of both, Nate. So certainly, a number of these initiatives have what I'll call long tail. They take a number of years to fully realize the benefits. And so a number of steps, but we're [ph] continuing to roll out new technology in the Institutional field force. And so we certainly are already absorbing the costs associated with that but haven't fully realized the benefits and won't [ph] for a couple of years, meaning it will continue to increase in benefits, but I don't think you're going to be at full run rate for a few years. It just takes a while to change. Half is in practices, [ph] take out the costs that are [ph] obsolete, et cetera. In the manufacturing and product supply area, which we always said was going to be the last frontier for synergies, and -- so we can't call them synergies anymore, but we are getting after a number of opportunities in product supply because we now have a full handle on what the networks looks like today and what we think it ought to [ph] look like going forward, and there is significant opportunities there that our product supply team is after. So we don't feel we're impaired in terms of opportunities to continue to drive productivity and margin enhancements as we go forward. And I would expect as we continue to add businesses through M&A that we will continue to see additional opportunities arise.

componenttext: Okay. And then second question, I realize this is likely probably not going to be a '17 event but then going forward, hopefully, the economy at best maybe stay or hopefully at least stay sluggish if not gets a little bit better over that time, but how do you think about at some point in terms of balancing as you kind of recapture the energy business a little bit, and hopefully we have those less FX headwinds, how do you think about letting that margin flow through to the bottom line back to shareholders versus -- and when do you kind of kick up the reinvestment rate a little bit?[ph][ph]

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think there'll be -- as the energy business recovers, there's a number of things. I mean, as we watch volumes degrade [ph] there, it is a more harmful process than simply you lose the OI, particularly because you'll lose the overhead coverage in y
componenttext: Well, I think there'll be -- as the energy business recovers, there's a number of things. I mean, as we watch volumes degrade [ph] there, it is a more harmful process than simply you lose the OI, particularly because you'll lose the overhead coverage in your plans. So I think you're right. As energy volume comes back, you're going to see sort of outsize contributions in the near term as you build volume back in your plans. We will use some of that, what I will call extra contribution to reinvest back in the energy business where it makes sense, but we aren't going to be I think overzealous of those investments. We want to see full recovery and make sure that we're investing as the business comes back, and we'd rather be 2 weeks late than 2 weeks early on that recovery because it's so hard to predict. So I don't know if that answers fully your question. But I don't feel like we've got huge pent-up investment demands in the balance of the business, and what I tried to highlight in the opening comments were we have been increasing our investments in these last 2 years in spite of FX and energy headwinds. It's important to continue to do that in the business. We have a relatively long-term view of the business, and so I don't feel like the cupboards [ph] are bare that are going to need to be restocked per se from an investment standpoint as a consequence.

componenttext: No, I mean our Latin America business, I mean, they're certainly not being driven by a great underlying economy. We're having several things going on there. With that said, we're also getting pricing, fairly significant pricing as a consequence of the devaluation that have occurred down there from a currency standpoint. That begets inflation. I would expect that, that business is going to remain fairly resilient and have strong performance for the quarters to come.

But if you take that out, it's going to be consistent with the 6% plus the benefit of the recall comp. And then next year, we look at this moving from mid-single digits to upper single digits. So I think we're on the right track.

componenttext: Yes, I didn't fully get [ph] the last. So raw materials, Laurence, I mean, we're forecasting will start moving kind of enterprise-wide in 2017. componenttext: A couple of things. First of all, just wanted to understand the performance of the water business in the quarter. It was sort of coming along in kind of mid-single digit same currency growth and then it was basically flat. This quarter, you talked about some declines in demand in Asia, particularly China as well as the mining market impact, and then -- but you were, I guess, a little bit more bullish in the mining expectation for the fourth quarter. So can you talk a little bit about what -- sort of what the trends are in water? Why China was down? Was it all because of the mining? Or was there some other slowdown going on? And what gives you the confidence that, that business is going to come back in the fourth quarter?

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, mining is a case of -- mining has been down double digits here for 4 [ph] quarters, and that's sort of the secret. We're lapping Q4 last year [ph] was the first real pain that we saw in mining as it reflected the pain broadly in the mining mark
componenttext: Yes, well, mining is a case of -- mining has been down double digits here for 4 [ph] quarters, and that's sort of the secret. We're lapping Q4 last year [ph] was the first real pain that we saw in mining as it reflected the pain broadly in the mining market. So mining, based on new business and, frankly, lapping Q4 of last year, we are pretty confident it's going to be, let's just say, neutral at worst, maybe minorly [ph] positive at best year-on-year. So the negative influence for mining is going to abate, and mining will turn positive as you move into 2017. The other mark that you mentioned is China, and that's really pain we feel on the heavy side of that business, and that's a reflection of steel, [ph] overcapacity, some being taken off line, mining also in China and also somewhat paper. Our paper results globally were positive, but they were much more positive than that if you took out the mining or the China results. And ultimately, we look at that, we're going to start lapping those comps starting a little bit in the first quarter next year and really fully after the second quarter next year. And so we look at that as an improving situation as we move through 2017 as well. Otherwise, I mean, the water business is doing quite well. So the light business continues to perform, which continue to drive great innovation there. That's the largest segment that we're in. It's also the most profitable. It'll de-emphasized and re-emphasized [ph] it to a significant positive effect. And the heavy side is starting to do a good job generating new business. It's going to start lapping some of the industrial slowdown like our [ph] more reasonable comps for this environment, and so I think you'll see some of that good work coming through.

componenttext: Okay. And then just touching on energy as my follow-up. componenttext: Yes, well, first, Dmitry, I mean, [indiscernible] your question I'll answer, I'll just say, last year, energy was down under -- just under 10%, more like 9%. And this year, we're saying it's going to be down what I think [ph] we said 10% to 12% or 12%. So it's not down 30% over the last couple of years, right? It's down considerably less than that. And we also aren't predicting a fourth quarter in the range that you cited either. It's going to be down modestly worse year-on-year than the third quarter simply because the fourth quarter comps of last year included a number of onetime issues, which we identified last year in the fourth quarter, it [ph] was a little bit inflated, if you will. But sequentially, the energy business in the fourth quarter this year versus third quarter this year is going to be quite consistent. So we've improved. The top line run rate is stabilized. OI run rate has improved throughout the year. So we're going to enter the year with what I would call top line stable, OI margin momentum as we go in. So yes, it's going to take a little while to build this business back and regain the 20% we lost. What we've tried to signal is this isn't going to be a 1 year phenomenon, and I don't know if it's going to take 2 years or 2.5 years at this point in time, but it's certainly going to take longer than 1 year to build it [ph] back. We said next year, we expect to be positive on the top line but modestly positive because we also think it's going to be a modest recovery in the oil markets.

componenttext: Well, I would say, I'll answer the energy question first. componenttext: Yes, I'd say it's principally that there are some technologies turned off because of their cash position. And so these are technologies that they'll turn off in very dire times, but they will end up turning it back on because it's not very smart economically if it's turned off a long period of time because you're going to be basically blowup your pipe, and you got a big capital problem if you want to continue to flow of material. So it's a number of those instances and that business we anticipate would come back as price and customer cash flow stabilize.

We continue to invest in field technology and also what I'll call customers connectivity technology. We collect data in nearly a million sites around the world, and we want to make sure that we connect the data collection capability with the cloud so that we can better utilize it to inform our sales team in advance of what's going on, better direct them to sales opportunities how to help the customer drive efficiency in both new sales productivity and in just selling time productivity as you go forward. We continue to invest in core ERP capabilities throughout the company, together the number of ERP systems we have around the world, we turned Canada on in the second quarter. We typically don't talk about these things as we go through them because we typically don't have big issues as we turn them on. And so we're continuing to invest there as we move forward until those areas also getting what I would call historically outsize investments as we upgrade those capabilities, which we think are really important for us long term and something that we think's manageable in our P&L as we move forward.

And so we have had a lot of success I think attracting great people, but we want to continue to improve our capabilities there. We track by business, by market more than 172 of them, how we do in terms of keeping our people, developing our people and promoting our people, and we want to continue to increase our capabilities in all those areas because we think that's going to increasingly become very important source of long-term competitiveness.

componenttext: I think the wild cards will be #1, FX. It's also impossible to predict, I guess, I just did. So that would be the wild card. Again, I don't think it's fundamental to what's going on in the business and long term that turns the other way some day. I just don't know when it is. I think that's something we're just going to have to manage and be nimble. And then finally, oil, which I would say is probably more likely an upsides than downside to price, but it could go either way as we all know. Oil will be the other one that you would say I think we've got this fairly in a comfortable zone. We're not expecting a nearly upside benefit from a big market upturn from oil. I don't think you're going to see it in any case in the first half. Second half, you could start arguing a case, probably more likely upside versus our forecast than downside.

componenttext: Yes, we divested the restroom cleaning portion of Swisher, which was Swisher's original business, and that was a business that we always intended to divest even when we bought it. I mean, I guess, we had open minds and proved to us to be a lot more valuable to us than what we suspected going in, but we never saw that business as a great fit for the way that we conduct business. It's a good business. It's not necessarily the business for us to own. And so as a consequence, we divested it. We thought we'd be able to divest that a lot quicker than we did. If anything, it slowed us down on a few areas of synergies that we are now getting after, i.e., we have to keep our operating in Charlotte open much longer than anticipated and some other things because that's where that business is going to run out of. And so we'll got on with it. Swisher acquisition I would say is largely untracked if you're going to pin me down and say where is it exactly, I mean, it's behind by weeks and it's in a position where that team will catch-up quite quickly now that, that divestiture is behind us, so that deals going to ultimately turn out to be a absolute home run financially for us. It's just been a heck of a lot of work in terms of transitioning all the products of our formula, moving them, we're still during production. One, their warehouse to our warehouse and their factory to our factory, changing the way that they distribute because a lot of distributed by individual salespeople. It was in Swisher and obviously that's not how we distribute our product for safety reasons as well as just control reasons and utilization of sales time efficiency. So for all kinds of reasons, there's a lot of transitioning going on, all of it's going quite well, but it's a lot of work. And so I know that teams looking forward to start getting to more normal operating situations, which they're entering now Q4 and Q1.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Hello, everyone, and welcome to Ecolab's third quarter conference call. With me today is Doug Baker, Ecolab's Chairman and CEO; and Dan Schmechel, our CFO.A discussion of our results, along with our earnings release and the slides referencing
componenttext:
Thank you. Hello, everyone, and welcome to Ecolab's third quarter conference call. With me today is Doug Baker, Ecolab's Chairman and CEO; and Dan Schmechel, our CFO.
A discussion of our results, along with our earnings release and the slides referencing our quarter's results, and our outlook are available on Ecolab's website at ecolab.com/investor. Please take a moment to read the cautionary statements on these materials stating that this teleconference, the discussion and the slides include estimates of future performance. These are forward-looking statements, and actual results could differ materially from those projected. Factors that could cause actual results to differ are described in the section of our most recent Form 10-K under the Item 1A, Risk Factors, and in our posted materials. We also refer you to the supplemental diluted earnings per share information in the release.
Starting with a brief overview of the quarter, continued attractive new business gains and new product introductions drove acquisition-adjusted fixed currency sales growth in our Institutional, Industrial and Other segments during the third quarter, offsetting a moderated decline in energy sales. Product innovation, lower deliberate product costs and ongoing cost-efficiency work led to strong adjusted fixed currency operating margin expansion, more than offsetting the impact of soft economies, challenging end markets and continued currency headwinds. These drove the 7% adjusted earnings per share increase before currency translation.
Looking to the fourth quarter. We expect our Institutional, Industrial and Other segments to show a modestly better year-on-year acquisition-adjusted fixed currency growth versus the third quarter, outpacing their markets and soft international economies as they leverage investments we've made to further improve sales and service force effectiveness and profitability.
We expect lower year-on-year results from our energy business. We look for our fourth quarter adjusted diluted earnings per share to be in the $1.23 to $1.33 range, with that range including approximately $0.02 per share of unfavorable impact from the Venezuela devaluation and deconsolidation and currency translation as we continue to aggressively drive business growth.
We have narrowed our forecast for the full year 2016 to the $4.35 to $4.45 range from $4.35 to $4.50, which includes expected currency headwinds of approximately $0.30 per share, of which $0.17 per share is from the Venezuela devaluation and deconsolidation.
Moving to some highlights from the quarter. As discussed in our press release, third quarter diluted earnings per share were $1.27. On an adjusted basis, excluding special gains and charges and discrete tax items from both years, third quarter 2016 adjusted diluted earnings per share were $1.28 and included a $0.09 or 7 percentage point currency headwind. This compared with adjusted diluted earnings per share of $1.28 a year ago.
Our consolidated acquisition-adjusted fixed currency sales were modestly higher as our Institutional, Industrial and Other segments grew 3% but were offset by lower energy sales. Regional sales growth was led by Latin America.
Reported operating margins increased 500 basis points. Adjusted fixed currency operating margins expanded 60 basis points as continued sales growth from the Institutional, Industrial and Other segments, lower delivered product cost and cost efficiencies more than offset investments in the business and lower energy results.
In 2016's difficult operating environment, we have focused on driving new business gains by helping customers to lower their costs. We are using our industry-leading product innovation and service strengths to help customers achieve the best results and the lowest operating cost and, through these, aggressively drive new account gains across all of our segments.
We expect fourth quarter earnings per share in the $1.23 to $1.33 range, reflecting currency translation drag of approximately $0.02. We narrowed our full year earnings per share forecast to the $4.35 to $4.45 range, and this forecast includes expected unfavorable currency translation, a currency exchange of approximately $0.30 per share, of which $0.17 per share is from the Venezuela devaluation and deconsolidation.
In summary, despite a very challenging global economic and market environment, we expect to deliver solid fundamental results in 2016. We remain confident in our business, our markets and our people as well as our capacities to meet our aggressive growth objectives over the coming years.
And now here's Doug Baker with some comments.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. Look, my headline would be solid quarter, headwinds are easing, and we believe we're in a good position as we close out the year. So let me go through each of these briefly.So first, the quarter. I would describe it as better than it looks
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike. Look, my headline would be solid quarter, headwinds are easing, and we believe we're in a good position as we close out the year. So let me go through each of these briefly.
So first, the quarter. I would describe it as better than it looks. The Institutional business, if you look at the underlying sales particularly in North America, which is a big piece of the business, they remained consistent with the first half in Q3. The noise in this quarter was really in the U.S. distribution channel, and we expect Q4 sales to bounce back to the level that we were seeing prior to Q3.
QSR and FRS, our Food Retail and quick service businesses, remained quite strong. Our F&B business was solid. We've got good new business. We expect that business to accelerate in 2017. The water business, mining declined, eclipsed mid-single-digit light industry growth and low single-digit heavy industry growth. Mining is expected to rebound in Q4 as it hits easier comps and also benefits from new sales, so the water business will look much better in Q4 and throughout 2017.
The Healthcare business grew at a healthy 6%. We expect an even better Q4 as it laps last year's recall and continues to benefit from new business efforts and successes that we're having. So this business is really gaining traction.
Pest and Equipment Care were quite strong and expect to remain strong. Energy stabilized. So our sales of $760 million in Q3 are consistent with both Q2 and Q1. Our OI in Q3, however, is much better as reformulations, synergies and other savings take hold.
As we look to Q4, we expect the results to be quite similar to Q3, call it plus/minus. Sales likely to be a bit better, OI maybe a touch weaker as we will take down 2 plants for refurbishment. And we're doing that just to be prepared, if we're surprised on the upside next year, we don't want to be in a position where we have to take them down at that time.
So we expect to leave the year with very good momentum and fewer hills to climb. The external environment continues to be challenging, and it's mixed but we believe manageable from an economic standpoint. Raw materials are expected to increase, but we can manage via pricing and cost savings, we have in the past, and we don't see this as spiky. We see it as fairly gradual.
FX is easing. So on our first quarter, FX is a 14% headwind, and it's roughly a 1% headwind in Q4. We assume we're highly unlikely to see another 7% full year challenge in 2017.
Energy has stabilized, and if market only stands still here, it will likely or should be an accretive year even in those conditions for us in 2017. Internally, we've also continued to have great success with new business and our innovation pipeline. We've also maintained investments throughout this year. We invested more in '16 than '15, and '15 was larger in the investment category than '14, so we continue to build on what we think are core investments for the future. So we've not, if you will, emptied the cabinet there by any means.
We've also rebuilt bonus, taken down inventory as well as the absorption hit that this typically drives, so we leave the year whole is what I would say. So while it's too early for 2017 forecast, we're just, frankly, in the middle of our planning season, we feel like we're sitting in a good position leaving the year to deliver significantly improved 2017.
So those are my opening comments. With that, I'll turn it back to Mike.

componenttext: Great. And then just a follow-up on the non-energy businesses. You've done outstanding job the last 18 months driving consistent margin expansion in all of those businesses to offset the energy weakness. Has there -- I know you said you've been investing a lot, but is there a risk that if energy takes longer to come back that it just becomes much more difficult, I guess, particularly with raw's prices likely going up in the first half of next year to sustain the momentum on a constant currency basis? Obviously, FX look like it's going to be a lot less of a drag.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, Gary, I guess, the FX, it hits you in transaction and translation. And transaction is like inflation, and we mitigate that. But the translation, there's nothing to do. And FX has really been the problem that's been the most challenging for u
componenttext: Yes, I think, Gary, I guess, the FX, it hits you in transaction and translation. And transaction is like inflation, and we mitigate that. But the translation, there's nothing to do. And FX has really been the problem that's been the most challenging for us in the gate because it's not going to justify any pricing or driving pricing in the market. Raw materials, I think we've proven over the years that when the raws start moving, we typically can go command additional pricing as a consequence. We continue to drive mix through new technology upgrades in our customers, and of course, we've got to benefit the customers financially as well. And we've got what I would say very strong momentum in our supply chain around what we call structural savings. So I'm really not that nervous about what we believe is going to happen in the raw material markets, which we believe raws are going to move up next year, but we do believe we're going to move up in a fairly orderly fashion as we go, but we have that fully forecasted in our business. I don't think that's going to drive or negate our ability to continue to drive margin expansion in those businesses. And I would say we didn't drive margin just because oil was down. I mean, we were driving margin when oil was up in a number of those businesses. That's kind of our constant. We want profitable growth, continue to drive mix in a favorable way, watch our spending, continue to get productivity, and those are going to be the same focus areas next year as well.

componenttext: Hey, Doug, I wanted to chat about 2 things. One, just when you think about all those productivity improvements, and obviously, we always talk about that in terms of Ecolab playbook and you always have another 10 ready to go, but everything that you've done here recently that's shown up in terms of driving that OI and your confidence heading into next year, are all of those things that you put in place gradually or put in place a couple of years ago to help drive this? Or are these all recent initiatives that are just starting?

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's some of both, Nate. So certainly, a number of these initiatives have what I'll call long tail. They take a number of years to fully realize the benefits. And so a number of steps, but we're continuing to roll out new technology in the Instituti
componenttext: Well, it's some of both, Nate. So certainly, a number of these initiatives have what I'll call long tail. They take a number of years to fully realize the benefits. And so a number of steps, but we're continuing to roll out new technology in the Institutional field force. And so we certainly are already absorbing the costs associated with that but haven't fully realized the benefits and won't for a couple of years, meaning it will continue to increase in benefits, but I don't think you're going to be at full run rate for a few years. It just takes a while to change. Happens in practices, take out the cost that is obsolete, et cetera. In the manufacturing and product supply area, which we always said was going to be the last frontier for synergies, and -- so we can't call them synergies anymore, but we are getting after a number of opportunities in product supply because we now have a full handle on what the networks looks like today and what we think it ought to look like going forward, and there is significant opportunities there that our product supply team is after. So we don't feel we're impaired in terms of opportunities to continue to drive productivity and margin enhancements as we go forward. And I would expect as we continue to add businesses through M&A that we will continue to see additional opportunities arise.

componenttext: Okay. And then second question, I realize this is likely probably not going to be a '17 event but then going forward, hopefully, the economy at best maybe stay or hopefully at least stay sluggish if not gets a little bit better over that time. But how do you think about at some point in terms of balancing as you kind of recapture the energy business a little bit, and hopefully we have those less FX headwinds, how do you think about letting that margin flow through to the bottom line back to shareholders versus -- and when do you kind of kick up the reinvestment rate a little bit?

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think there'll be -- as the energy business recovers, there's a number of things. I mean, as we watch volumes degrade there, it is a more harmful process than simply you lose the OI, particularly because you'll lose the overhead coverage in your p
componenttext: Well, I think there'll be -- as the energy business recovers, there's a number of things. I mean, as we watch volumes degrade there, it is a more harmful process than simply you lose the OI, particularly because you'll lose the overhead coverage in your plans. So I think you're right. As energy volume comes back, you're going to see sort of outsize contributions in the near term as you build volume back in your plans. We will use some of that, what I will call extra contribution to reinvest back in the energy business where it makes sense, but we aren't going to be I think overzealous of those investments. We want to see full recovery and make sure that we're investing as the business comes back, and we'd rather be 2 weeks late than 2 weeks early on that recovery because it's so hard to predict. So I don't know if that answers fully your question. But I don't feel like we've got huge pent-up investment demands in the balance of the business, and what I tried to highlight in the opening comments were we have been increasing our investments in these last 2 years in spite of FX and energy headwinds. It's important to continue to do that in the business. We have a relatively long-term view of the business, and so I don't feel like the cupboards are bare, that are going to need to be restocked per se from an investment standpoint as a consequence.

componenttext: A couple of things. First of all, just wanted to understand the performance of the water business in the quarter. It was sort of coming along in kind of mid-single digit same currency growth and then it was basically flat. This quarter, you talked about some declines in demand in Asia, particularly China as well as the mining market impact, and then -- but you were, I guess, a little bit more bullish in the mining expectation for the fourth quarter. So can you talk a little bit about what -- sort of what the trends are in water? Why China was down? Was it all because of the mining? Or was there some other slowdown going on? And what gives you the confidence that, that business is going to come back in the fourth quarter?

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, mining is a case of -- mining has been down double digits here for 4 quarters, and that's sort of the secret. We're lapping Q4 last year, was the first real pain that we saw in mining as it reflected the pain broadly in the mining market. So mi
componenttext: Yes, well, mining is a case of -- mining has been down double digits here for 4 quarters, and that's sort of the secret. We're lapping Q4 last year, was the first real pain that we saw in mining as it reflected the pain broadly in the mining market. So mining, based on new business and, frankly, lapping Q4 of last year, we are pretty confident it's going to be, let's just say, neutral at worst, maybe minorly positive at best year-on-year. So the negative influence for mining is going to abate, and mining will turn positive as you move into 2017. The other mark that you mentioned is China, and that's really pain we feel on the heavy side of that business, and that's a reflection of steel overcapacity, some being taken off line, mining also in China and also somewhat paper. Our paper results globally were positive, but they were much more positive than that if you took out the mining or the China results. And ultimately, we look at that, we're going to start lapping those comps starting a little bit in the first quarter next year and really fully after the second quarter next year. And so we look at that as an improving situation as we move through 2017 as well. Otherwise, I mean, the water business is doing quite well. So the light business continues to perform, which continue to drive great innovation there. That's the largest segment that we're in. It's also the most profitable. It had been deemphasized, and we have reemphasized it to a significant positive effect. And the heavy side is starting to do a good job generating new business. It's going to start lapping some of the industrial slowdown like our more reasonable comps for this environment, and so I think you'll see some of that good work coming through.

componenttext: Okay. And then just touching on energy as my follow-up. So are you starting to see the weakness spread into the balance stream in the refining business? Is it mostly pricing or volume or a combination thereof? And are we just basically looking for 2017, where we're stabilizing at these levels but not seeing much of an improvement on the top line as we go through the year?

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, first, Dmitry, I mean, your question I'll answer, I'll just say, last year, energy was down under -- just under 10%, more like 9%. And this year, we're saying it's going to be down what I think we said 10% to 12% or 12%. So it's not down 30% ov
componenttext: Yes, well, first, Dmitry, I mean, your question I'll answer, I'll just say, last year, energy was down under -- just under 10%, more like 9%. And this year, we're saying it's going to be down what I think we said 10% to 12% or 12%. So it's not down 30% over the last couple of years, right? It's down considerably less than that. And we also aren't predicting a fourth quarter in the range that you cited either. It's going to be down modestly worse year-on-year than the third quarter simply because the fourth quarter comps of last year included a number of onetime issues, which we identified last year in the fourth quarter was a little bit inflated, if you will. But sequentially, the energy business in the fourth quarter this year versus third quarter this year is going to be quite consistent. So we've improved. The top line run rate is stabilized. OI run rate has improved throughout the year. So we're going to enter the year with what I would call top line stable, OI margin momentum as we go in. So yes, it's going to take a little while to build this business back and regain the 20% we lost. What we've tried to signal is this isn't going to be a 1 year phenomenon, and I don't know if it's going to take 2 years or 2.5 years at this point in time, but it's certainly going to take longer than 1 year to build it back. We said next year, we expect to be positive on the top line but modestly positive because we also think it's going to be a modest recovery in the oil markets.

componenttext: Yes, I don't know. QSR, there's -- if you look at those industry trends, I mean, it hasn't really accelerated. I mean, it's continued to kind of hold its own. If there's been any trading from top-down, it's probably more in the fast casual segment and those other segments of the market less so than from QSR, I think. Our strength there is what we built on. We've got very deep relationships. We worked very hard to help our customers there react to the environments they find themselves in. Currently, it's not a perfect top line environment for those businesses, and they're having real cost pressures underneath, particularly from both wage and also benefit pressure, i.e., ACA. And so we're doing a lot of work there trying to help them take labor out of those businesses because they have to, given this environment. And so that will allow for new technology for us, but it's a huge financial benefit for them, and that's how we're working at that market and why I still am quite bullish in our ability to continue to grow in QSR going forward.

componenttext: Well, I would say -- I'll answer the energy question first. I mean, we did an acquisition in energy not that long ago. And I think, as I reflected in other answers on this question around energy M&A, it's sort of a situation that if you don't have to sell right now, most people aren't in the mood to sell. They can think it make through because I think everybody feels like these things bottomed and better times are ahead for them both on a multiple and an EBITDA absolute basis. So it's not -- there's not a lot of for sale signs out there from a lot of people. There are going to be exceptions, and there's been a notable one this week. So I guess I'd be a little surprised if we end up doing any real energy M&A in the near term for that reason. In terms of where else, yes, I would say, look, if we're in a business, we're in it to go grow. M&A is one of the growth tools that we use to supplement organic growth. And if we found other smart deals in Institutional, F&B, water, Healthcare, sort of you name it, we'd be interested. What would our wish list be? I think we've strategically said we want to continue to build the Healthcare business, i.e., the you'd seen the Anios, recent acquisition, and water just because the market probably hasn't been penetrated with small M&A deals like some of our others, that would also be a place that we would think might be richer environment.

componenttext: Yes, Mike, we get this periodically. I mean, it's just, typically, we assume that out from the distributor are going to generate an equal number of ins, i.e., orders to the distributor from us. We have great transparency here as you know, meaning we had printouts from each of our distributor partners about what were -- what exact case went to what exact customer and at what price. I mean, it could be as simple as we're watching these things run through here. These things happen I would say episodically. I mean, it's happened a number of times. I ran that business. So the U.S. consumption was at 6.3% in the third quarter compared to 6.4% through acquisition adjusted in the second quarter, that's not any meaningful difference. And so we're quite confident that business continues to run well.

componenttext: All right. And then in the comments that you guys provided on energy, you referenced lower customer product usage within the production side of the energy business. And I was wondering how much flexibility do customers have on reducing chemical use? And is this a situation where they can only do that for so long, and then we'd expect to see the usage rebound? Or does it have more to do with the mix of production coming from more sources that are using less of your chemicals on a per barrel basis?

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say it's principally that there are some technologies they just turned off because of their cash position. And so some anti-corrosion products, these -- you don't see corrosion in a month or even a year, it's over a period of time. And so these a
componenttext: Yes, I'd say it's principally that there are some technologies they just turned off because of their cash position. And so some anti-corrosion products, these -- you don't see corrosion in a month or even a year, it's over a period of time. And so these are technologies that they'll turn off in very dire times, but they will end up turning it back on because it's not very smart economically to have these turned off for a long period of time because you're going to be basically blow out your pipe. And then you've got a big capital problem if you want to continue the flow of material. So it's a number of those instances, and that business, we anticipate, would come back as price and customer cash flow stabilize.

componenttext: Yes, look, I'd say our investments are in several areas. I mean, certainly, we continue to add sales folks in the businesses that continue to show solid organic growth. We continue to invest in field technology and also what I'll call customer connectivity technology. We collect data in nearly a million customer sites around the world, and we want to make sure that we connect that data collection capability with the cloud so that we can better utilize it to inform our sales team in advance of what's going on, better direct them to sales opportunities, how to help the customer frankly drive efficiency in both new sales productivity and in just selling time productivity as we go forward. So that's an area that's getting a lot of work. We continue to invest in just core ERP capabilities throughout the company, knitting together the number of ERP systems we have around the world. We turned Canada on in the second quarter. We typically don't talk about these things as we go through them because we typically don't have big issues as we turn them on. And so we're continuing to invest there as we move forward, and so those areas are also getting what I would call historically outsize investments as we upgrade those capabilities, which we think are really important for us long term and something that we think is manageable in our P&L as we move forward.

componenttext: Doug, as we're heading here into 2017 and you're doing your planning process, I was just hoping you could outline for us what your key strategic priorities are going to be as you go into '17 and really what some of those swing factors that could affect, the key swing factors that you're looking at today as you handicap what '17 could look like. I would just want to see what's on your list of pluses and minuses there.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say in terms of driving the business, we mentioned this year, one of them -- we had a number of key strategic priorities. One was getting energy ready for what we call stabilization and kind of upturn, and I think we can check the box, and if
componenttext: Yes, I would say in terms of driving the business, we mentioned this year, one of them -- we had a number of key strategic priorities. One was getting energy ready for what we call stabilization and kind of upturn, and I think we can check the box, and if we feel like we're in good shape, they're moving into next year, so strategic priorities around driving the business or just making sure we continue to stick to the fundamentals. Driving new business, leverage innovation to do that as well as to build mix, profitable mix within the existing customer base, all the fundamentals that we typically drive. We've got some significant cost-savings initiatives that we're undertaking particularly in product supply, which I mentioned earlier, to make sure just from an operating standpoint we continue to build both top line and expand margins as we go forward. Longer term, there's probably 2 key areas that we're going to have outsize emphasis, one I just talked about in terms of field technology and customer connection technology. We're going to continue to invest there, make sure that we have a leadership position. We already have a huge installed base of information collection capability. We want to make sure that we fully leverage that to our advantage and our customers' advantage moving forward. So that's going to get an area. The second would be talent. And so we have had a lot of success, I think, attracting great people, but we want to continue to improve our capabilities there. We track by business, by market more than 172 of them, how we do in terms of keeping our people, developing our people and promoting our people, and we want to continue to increase our capabilities in all those areas because we think that's going to increasingly become a very important source of long-term competitiveness.

componenttextpreview: I think the wild cards would be number one, FX. And so I'm sitting here quite confident it's not going to be anywhere near 7% in terms of EPS headwind next year, but if you want something that can turn on a dime, it would be FX. It's also impossible to pr
componenttext: I think the wild cards would be number one, FX. And so I'm sitting here quite confident it's not going to be anywhere near 7% in terms of EPS headwind next year, but if you want something that can turn on a dime, it would be FX. It's also impossible to predict, I guess, I just did. So that would be the wild card. Again, I don't think it's fundamental to what's going on in the business and long term, that turns the other way some day. I just don't know when it is. The other area I think would be just kind of world economic health. I don't think the world's going to turn to recession, but it's kind of a flaky world right now, and it's almost a binary, things turn on and off much more rapidly than they did before. I think that's something we're just going to have to manage and be nimble. And then finally, oil, which I would say is probably more likely an upside than downside to price, but it could go either way as we all know. Oil will be the other one that you would say I think we've got this in cast fairly in kind of a comfortable zone. We are not expecting any really upside benefit from a big market upturn from oil. I don't think you're going to see it in any case in the first half. Second half, you could start arguing a case, probably more likely upside versus our forecast than downside.

componenttext: Pest business is fairly strong across the board, and I'm just trying to get my chart. I would say 2 things. The business is -- the pest business really takes off when you have some density. And so what we've been able to do in a number of what I would call is the Asia Pacific and Latin America markets is continuing to drive density, which will continue to drive much better leverage. Right now if you look at those markets, they are the lowest OI margins that we have, and it's really a consequence of the makeup of the business, i.e., smaller businesses that are growing but haven't quite achieved what I would call margin-efficient density level, but they will. So that's one of the reasons, I think, to be bullish in that business. All of them are growing quite well, and the growth in particularly Latin America and Asia Pacific is going to have outsize margin contribution as it starts overwhelming the overhead investments that we've already made.

componenttext: Yes, well, I mean, mining went through a free fall itself, and I think what we probably seen is some kind of stabilization in the base and -- of mining operators who I think can better predict going forward. componenttext: Yes, we divested the restroom cleaning portion of Swisher, which interestingly was Swisher's original business, and that was a business that we always intended to divest even when we bought it. I mean, I guess, we had open minds and if it proved to us to be a lot more valuable to us than we suspected going in, but we never saw that business as a great fit for the way that we conduct the business. It's a good business. It's just not necessarily a good business for  us to own. And so as a consequence, we divested it. We thought we'd be able to divest that a lot quicker than we did. If anything, it slowed us down on a few areas of synergies that we are now getting after, i.e., we have to keep our Operating Center in Charlotte open much longer than we anticipated and some other things because that's where that business is going to run out of. And so we'll got on with it. The Swisher acquisition I would say is largely untracked if you're going to pin me down and say where is it exactly, I mean, it's behind by weeks and it's in a position where that team will catch-up quite quickly now that, that divestiture is behind us, so that deals going to ultimately turn out to be a absolute home run financially for us. It's just been a heck of a lot of work in terms of transitioning all the products of our formula, moving them, we're still during production. One, their warehouse to our warehouse and their factory to our factory, changing the way that they distribute because a lot of it was distributed by individual salespeople. It was in Swisher, and obviously, that's not how we distribute our product for safety reasons as well as just control reasons and utilization of sales time efficiency, so for all kinds of reasons. So there's been a lot of transitioning going on, all of it's going quite well, but it's a lot of work. And so I know that team's looking forward to start getting to more normal operating situations, which they're entering now Q4 and Q1.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Hello, everyone, and welcome to Ecolab's third quarter conference call. With me today is Doug Baker, Ecolab's Chairman and CEO; and Dan Schmechel, our CFO.A discussion of our results, along with our earnings release and the slides referencing
componenttext:
Thank you. Hello, everyone, and welcome to Ecolab's third quarter conference call. With me today is Doug Baker, Ecolab's Chairman and CEO; and Dan Schmechel, our CFO.
A discussion of our results, along with our earnings release and the slides referencing our quarter's results, and our outlook are available on Ecolab's website at ecolab.com/investor. Please take a moment to read the cautionary statements on these materials stating that this teleconference, the discussion and the slides include estimates of future performance. These are forward-looking statements, and actual results could differ materially from those projected. Factors that could cause actual results to differ are described in the section of our most recent Form 10-K under the Item 1A, Risk Factors, and in our posted materials. We also refer you to the supplemental diluted earnings per share information in the release.
Starting with a brief overview of the quarter, continued attractive new business gains and new product introductions drove acquisition-adjusted fixed currency sales growth in our Institutional, Industrial and Other segments during the third quarter, offsetting a moderated decline in energy sales. Product innovation, lower deliberate product costs and ongoing cost-efficiency work led the strong adjusted fixed currency operating margin expansion, more than offsetting the impact of soft economies, challenging end markets and continued currency headwinds. These drove the 7% adjusted earnings per share increase before currency translation.
Looking to the fourth quarter. We expect our Institutional, Industrial and Other segments to show a modestly better year-on-year acquisition-adjusted fixed currency growth versus the third quarter, outpacing their markets and soft international economies as they leverage investments we've made to further improve sales and service force effectiveness and profitability.
We expect lower year-on-year results from our energy business. We look for our fourth quarter adjusted diluted earnings per share to be in the $1.23 to $1.33 range, with that range including approximately $0.02 per share of unfavorable impact from the Venezuela devaluation and deconsolidation and currency translation as we continue to aggressively drive business growth.
We have narrowed our forecast for the full year 2016 to the $4.35 to $4.45 range from $4.35 to $4.50, which includes expected currency headwinds of approximately $0.30 per share, of which $0.17 per share is from the Venezuela devaluation and deconsolidation.
Moving to some highlights from the quarter. As discussed in our press release, third quarter diluted earnings per share were $1.27. On an adjusted basis, excluding special gains and charges and discrete tax items from both years, third quarter 2016 adjusted diluted earnings per share were $1.28 and included a $0.09 or 7 percentage point currency headwind. This compared with adjusted diluted earnings per share of $1.28 a year ago.
Our consolidated acquisition-adjusted fixed currency sales were modestly higher as our Institutional, Industrial and Other segments grew 3% but were offset by lower energy sales. Regional sales growth was led by Latin America.
Reported operating margins increased 500 basis points. Adjusted fixed currency operating margins expanded 60 basis points as continued sales growth from the Institutional, Industrial and Other segments, lower delivered product cost and cost efficiencies more than offset investments in the business and lower energy results.
In 2016's difficult operating environment, we have focused on driving new business gains by helping customers to lower their costs. We are using our industry-leading product innovation and service strengths to help customers achieve the best results and the lowest operating cost and, through these, aggressively drive new account gains across all of our segments.
We expect fourth quarter earnings per share in the $1.23 to $1.33 range, reflecting currency translation drag of approximately $0.02. We narrowed our full year earnings per share forecast to the $4.35 to $4.45 range, and this forecast includes expected unfavorable currency translation, a currency exchange of approximately $0.30 per share, of which $0.17 per share is from the Venezuela devaluation and deconsolidation.
In summary, despite a very challenging global economic and market environment, we expect to deliver solid fundamental results in 2016. We remain confident in our business, our markets and our people as well as our capacities to meet our aggressive growth objectives over the coming years.
And now here's Doug Baker with some comments.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. Look, my headline would be solid quarter, headwinds are easing, and we believe we're in a good position as we close out the year. So let me go through each of these briefly.So first, the quarter. I would describe it as better than it looks
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike. Look, my headline would be solid quarter, headwinds are easing, and we believe we're in a good position as we close out the year. So let me go through each of these briefly.
So first, the quarter. I would describe it as better than it looks. The Institutional business, if you look at the underlying sales particularly in North America, which is the big piece of the business, they remained consistent with the first half in Q3. The noise in this quarter was really in the U.S. distribution channel, and we expect Q4 sales to bounce back to the level that we were seeing prior to Q3.
QSR and FRS, our Food Retail and quick service businesses, remained quite strong. Our F&B business was solid. We've got good new business. We expect that business to accelerate in 2017. The water business, mining declined, eclipsed mid-single-digit light industry growth and low single-digit heavy industry growth. Mining is expected to rebound in Q4 as it hits easier comps and also benefits from new sales, so the water business will look much better in Q4 and throughout 2017.
The Healthcare business grew at a healthy 6%. We expect an even better Q4 as it laps last year's recall and continues to benefit from new business efforts and successes that we're having. So this business is really gaining traction.
Pest and Equipment Care were quite strong and expect to remain strong. Energy stabilized. So our sales of $760 million in Q3 are consistent with both Q2 and Q1. Our OI in Q3, however, is much better as reformulations, synergies and other savings take hold.
As we look to Q4, we expect the results to be quite similar to Q3. I'd call it plus/minus. Sales likely to be a bit better, OI maybe a touch weaker as we will take down 2 plants for refurbishment. And we're doing that just to be prepared. If we're surprised on the upside next year, we don't want to be in a position where we have to take them down at that time.
So we expect to leave the year with very good momentum and fewer hills to climb. The external environment continues to be challenging, and it's mixed but we believe manageable from an economic standpoint. Raw materials are expected to increase, but we can manage via pricing and cost savings, we have in the past, and we don't see this as spiky. We see it as fairly gradual.
FX is easing. So on our first quarter, FX is a 14% headwind, and it's roughly a 1% headwind in Q4. We assume we're highly unlikely to see another 7% full year challenge in 2017.
Energy has stabilized, and if market only stands still here, it will likely or should be an accretive year even in those conditions for us in 2017. Internally, we've also continued to have great success with new business and our innovation pipeline. We've also maintained investments throughout this year. We invested more in '16 than '15, and '15 was larger in the investment category than '14, so we continue to build on what we think are core investments for the future. So we've not, if you will, emptied the cabinet there by any means.
We've also rebuilt bonus, taken down inventory as well as the absorption hit that this typically drives, so we leave the year whole is what I would say. So while it's too early for 2017 forecast, we're just, frankly, in the middle of our planning season, we feel like we're sitting in a good position leaving the year to deliver significantly improved 2017.
So those are my opening comments. With that, I'll turn it back to Mike.

componenttext: Yes, I mean, a lot of it, Gary, is just the timing of our OI improvement. So we made, what, mid-50s on roughly the same sales like $56 million, I think, in the first quarter on roughly the same sales that we had in the third quarter. We made nearly $100 million in the third quarter. And a lot of that is just timing. There's been a lot of great work done in the energy business to reformulate products, lower cost, position ourselves for what I would say improved margins going forward once the wind starts blowing in our direction again. So the consequence of that even in a relatively flat environment if you assume no material activity change, and we continue to generate around the same 750, 760 in sales a quarter, which is what we've done in the last 3 and are forecasting in 4, you're going to see OI lift just as a consequence of the timing of the OI improvement this year. Now what we think is going to happen next year is there'll be very modest improvement throughout the year, particularly in the second half of '17, but I caution we think it's modest. We don't think this is by any means set up for a V recovery. I'm talking about the overall energy market. In that environment, we think we'll have low single digit, mid-single-digit type sales and decent OI.

componenttext: Great. And then just a follow-up on the non-energy businesses. You've done an outstanding job the last 18 months driving consistent margin expansion in all of those businesses to offset the energy weakness. Has there -- I know you said you've been investing a lot, but is there a risk that if energy takes longer to come back that it just becomes much more difficult, I guess, particularly with raw's prices likely going up in the first half of next year to sustain the momentum on a constant currency basis? Obviously, FX looks like it's going to be a lot less of a drag.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, Gary, I guess, the FX, it hits you in transaction and translation. And transaction is like inflation, and we mitigate that. But the translation, there's nothing to do. And FX has really been the problem that's been the most challenging for u
componenttext: Yes, I think, Gary, I guess, the FX, it hits you in transaction and translation. And transaction is like inflation, and we mitigate that. But the translation, there's nothing to do. And FX has really been the problem that's been the most challenging for us to negate because it's not going to justify any pricing or drive any pricing in the market. Raw materials, I think we've proven over the years that when the raws start moving, we typically can go command additional pricing as a consequence. We continue to drive mix through technology upgrades in our customers, and of course, we've got to benefit to customers financially as well. And we've got what I would say very strong momentum in our supply chain around what we call structural savings. So I'm really not that nervous about what we believe is going to happen in the raw material markets, which we believe raws are going to move up next year, but we do believe we're going to move up in a fairly orderly fashion as we go, but we have that fully forecasted in our business. I don't think that's going to drive or negate our ability to continue to drive margin expansion in those businesses. And I would say we didn't drive margin just because oil was down. I mean, we were driving margin when oil was up in a number of those businesses. That's kind of our constant. We want profitable growth, continue to drive mix in a favorable way, watch our spending, continue to get productivity, and those are going to be the same focus areas next year as well.

componenttext: Hey, Doug, I wanted to chat about 2 things. One, just when you think about all those productivity improvements, and obviously, we always talk about that in terms of Ecolab playbook and you always have another 10 ready to go, but everything that you've done here recently that's shown up in terms of driving that OI and your confidence heading into next year, are all of those things that you put in place gradually or put in place a couple of years ago to help drive this? Or are these all recent initiatives that are just starting?

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's some of both, Nate. So certainly, a number of these initiatives have what I'll call long tails. They take a number of years to fully realize the benefits. And so a number of steps, but we're continuing to roll out new technology in the Institut
componenttext: Well, it's some of both, Nate. So certainly, a number of these initiatives have what I'll call long tails. They take a number of years to fully realize the benefits. And so a number of steps, but we're continuing to roll out new technology in the Institutional field force. And so we certainly are already absorbing the costs associated with that but haven't fully realized the benefits and won't for a couple of years, meaning it will continue to increase in benefits, but I don't think you're going to be at full run rate for a few years. It just takes a while to change. Happens in practices, take out the cost that is obsolete, et cetera. In the manufacturing and product supply area, which we always said was going to be the last frontier for synergies, and -- so we can't call them synergies anymore, but we are getting after a number of opportunities in product supply because we now have a full handle on what the networks looks like today and what we think it ought to look like going forward, and there is significant opportunities there that our product supply team is after. So we don't feel we're impaired in terms of opportunities to continue to drive productivity and margin enhancements as we go forward. And I would expect as we continue to add businesses through M&A that we will continue to see additional opportunities arise.

componenttext: Okay. And then second question, I realize this is likely probably not going to be a '17 event but then going forward, hopefully, the economy at best maybe stay or hopefully at least stay sluggish if not gets a little bit better over that time. But how do you think about at some point in terms of balancing as you kind of recapture the energy business a little bit, and hopefully we have those less FX headwinds, how do you think about letting that margin flow through to the bottom line back to shareholders versus -- and when do you kind of kick up the reinvestment rate a little bit?

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think there'll be -- as the energy business recovers, there's a number of things. I mean, as we watch volumes degrade there, it is a more harmful process than simply you lose the OI, particularly because you'll lose the overhead coverage in your p
componenttext: Well, I think there'll be -- as the energy business recovers, there's a number of things. I mean, as we watch volumes degrade there, it is a more harmful process than simply you lose the OI, particularly because you'll lose the overhead coverage in your plans. So I think you're right. As energy volume comes back, you're going to see sort of outsize contributions in the near term as you build volume back in your plans. We will use some of that, what I will call extra contribution to reinvest back in the energy business where it makes sense, but we aren't going to be I think overzealous of those investments. We want to see full recovery and make sure that we're investing as the business comes back, and we'd rather be 2 weeks late than 2 weeks early on that recovery because it's so hard to predict. So I don't know if that answers fully your question. But I don't feel like we've got huge pent-up investment demands in the balance of the business, and what I tried to highlight in the opening comments were we have been increasing our investments in these last 2 years in spite of FX and energy headwinds. It's important to continue to do that in the business. We have a relatively long-term view of the business, and so I don't feel like the cupboards are bare, that are going to need to be restocked per se from an investment standpoint as a consequence.

We're going to have to continue to do what we do in pricing, continue to do what we do on mix, continue what we do on cost savings. And I think, those 3 tools are more than sufficient to offset what we see in terms of raw material inflation next year.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of things. First of all, just want to understand the performance of the water business in the quarter. It was sort of coming along in kind of mid-single digit same currency growth and then it was basically flat. This quarter, you talked about som
componenttext: A couple of things. First of all, just want to understand the performance of the water business in the quarter. It was sort of coming along in kind of mid-single digit same currency growth and then it was basically flat. This quarter, you talked about some declines in demand in Asia, particularly China as well as the mining market impact, and then -- but you were, I guess, a little bit more bullish in the mining expectation for the fourth quarter. So can you talk a little bit about what -- sort of what the trends are in water? Why China was down? Was it all because of the mining? Or was there some other slowdown going on? And what gives you the confidence that, that business is going to come back in the fourth quarter?

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, mining is a case of -- mining has been down double digits here for 4 quarters, and that's sort of the secret. We're lapping Q4 last year, was the first real pain that we saw in mining as it reflected the pain broadly in the mining market. So mi
componenttext: Yes, well, mining is a case of -- mining has been down double digits here for 4 quarters, and that's sort of the secret. We're lapping Q4 last year, was the first real pain that we saw in mining as it reflected the pain broadly in the mining market. So mining, based on new business and, frankly, lapping Q4 of last year, we are pretty confident it's going to be, let's just say, neutral at worst, maybe minorly positive at best year-on-year. So the negative influence for mining is going to abate, and mining will turn positive as we move into 2017. The other mark that you mentioned is China, and that's really pain we feel on the heavy side of that business, and that's a reflection of steel overcapacity, some being taken off line, mining also in China and also somewhat paper. Our paper results globally were positive, but they were much more positive than that if you took out the mining or the China results. And ultimately, we look at that, we're going to start lapping those comps starting a little bit in the first quarter next year and really fully after the second quarter next year. And so we look at that as an improving situation as we move through 2017 as well. Otherwise, I mean, the water business is doing quite well. So the light business continues to perform, which continues to drive great innovation there. That's the largest segment that we're in. It's also the most profitable. It had been deemphasized, and we have reemphasized it to a significant positive effect. And the heavy side is starting to do a good job generating new business. It's going to start lapping some of the industrial slowdown like our more reasonable comps for this environment, and so I think you'll see some of that good work coming through.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just touching on energy briefly as my follow-up. You talked from your guidance like you expect another, I don't know, 17%, 18%, 19% somewhat decline in year-over-year sales in the fourth quarter, basically bringing your 2-year decline to ab
componenttext: Okay. And then just touching on energy briefly as my follow-up. You talked from your guidance like you expect another, I don't know, 17%, 18%, 19% somewhat decline in year-over-year sales in the fourth quarter, basically bringing your 2-year decline to about 30%. Clearly, that's gone beyond sort of the 10% of your business that was or 20% of the business at onetime that was the upstream business. So are you starting to see the weakness spread into the downstream in the refining business? Is it mostly pricing or volume or a combination thereof? And are we just basically looking for 2017, where we're stabilizing at these levels but not seeing much of an improvement on the top line as we go through the year?

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, first, Dmitry, I mean, some parts of your question I'll answer, I'll just say, last year, energy was down under -- just under 10%, more like 9%. And this year, we're saying it's going to be down what I think we said 10% to 12% or 12%. So it's n
componenttext: Yes, well, first, Dmitry, I mean, some parts of your question I'll answer, I'll just say, last year, energy was down under -- just under 10%, more like 9%. And this year, we're saying it's going to be down what I think we said 10% to 12% or 12%. So it's not down 30% over the last couple of years, right? It's down considerably less than that. And we also aren't predicting a fourth quarter in the range that you cited either. It's going to be down modestly worse year-on-year than the third quarter simply because the fourth quarter comps of last year included a number of onetime issues, which we identified last year in the fourth quarter. It was a little bit inflated, if you will. But sequentially, the energy business in the fourth quarter this year versus third quarter this year is going to be quite consistent. So we've improved. The top line run rate is stabilized. OI run rate has improved throughout the year. So we're going to enter the year with what I would call top line stable, OI margin momentum as we go in. So yes, it's going to take a little while to build this business back and regain the 20% we lost. What we've tried to signal is this isn't going to be a 1 year phenomenon, and I don't know if it's going to take 2 years or 2.5 years at this point in time, but it's certainly going to take longer than 1 year to build it back. We said next year, we expect to be positive on the top line but modestly positive because we also think it's going to be a modest recovery in the oil markets.

componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't know. QSR, there's -- if you look at those industry trends, I mean, it hasn't really accelerated. I mean, it's continued to kind of hold its own. If there's been any trading from top-down, it's probably more in the fast casual segment and tho
componenttext: Yes, I don't know. QSR, there's -- if you look at those industry trends, I mean, it hasn't really accelerated. I mean, it's continued to kind of hold its own. If there's been any trading from top-down, it's probably more in the fast casual segment and those other segments of the market less so than from QSR, I think. Our strength there is really built on-- we've got very deep relationships. We work very hard to help our customers there react to the environments they find themselves in. Currently, it's not a perfect top line environment for those businesses, and they're having real cost pressures underneath, particularly from both wage and also benefit pressure, i.e., ACA. And so we're doing a lot of work there trying to help them take labor out of those businesses because they have to, given this environment. And so that will allow for new technology for us, but it's a huge financial benefit for them, and that's how we're working at that market and why I still am quite bullish in our ability to continue to grow in QSR going forward.

componenttext: Well, I would say -- I'll answer the energy question first. I mean, we did an acquisition in energy not that long ago. And I think, as I reflected in other answers on this question around energy M&A, it's sort of a situation that if you don't have to sell right now, most people aren't in the mood to sell. If they can think it make through-- because I think everybody feels like these things bottomed and better times are ahead for them both on a multiple and an EBITDA absolute basis. So it's not -- there's not a lot of for sale signs out there from a lot of people. There are going to be exceptions, and there's been a notable one this week. So I guess I'd be a little surprised if we end up doing any real energy M&A in the near term for that reason. In terms of where else, yes, I would say, look, if we're in a business, we're in it to go grow. M&A is one of the growth tools that we use to supplement organic growth. And if we found other smart deals in Institutional, F&B, water, Healthcare, sort of you name it, we'd be interested. What would our wish list be? I think we've strategically said we want to continue to build the Healthcare business, i.e., the you'd seen the Anios, recent acquisition, and water just because the market probably hasn't been penetrated with small M&A deals like some of our others, that would also be a place that we would think might be richer environment.
